fields.headline: Reykjavik establishes Wei Yi as world's youngest grandmaster
fields.bodyText: Reykjavik is an iconic name for chess players, the venue for the most famous of all world title matches when Bobby Fischer beat Boris Spassky in 1972. So the annual Reykjavik Open, despite its modest €15,000 prize fund, always attracts a competitive grandmaster entry where top players from the United States, Western Europe, Russia and Asia jostle for supremacy. On the rest day many of the players went on Iceland's Golden Circle tour of the island's beauty spots, but with a difference: the final stop on the tour was Fischer's grave at Selfoss. Fischer played his 'Game of the Century' at 13 and another 13-year-old stole the show this week at Reykjavik. China's Wei Yi became the youngest GM in the world and the fourth youngest ever when he beat France's No1, Maxime Vachier-Lagrave, and finished tied fourth on 8/10, level with the British champion, Gawain Jones, who went through unbeaten. Wei Yi, remember that name. It could prove a portent for the future of chess. China already dominates the women's game and is now pouring resources into stepping up its efforts to achieve comparable results with teenage male talents. A little-known Scot made his mark in the early rounds. Hamilton's Andrew Muir, an amateur and journeyman master, had the purple patch of his life when he defeated two highly ranked GMs in succession. The first game was bizarre as his Egyptian opponent blundered a rook and resigned after 19 moves while in the second Muir missed a brilliancy featured in this week's puzzle. Egypt's No1 GM blundered badly by 17 Nxe5? when 17 Ng5+ or 17 Nh4 keeps a slight edge. Bassem Amin saw too late that his planned 19 Be4 to trap the queen fails to Qxe4! 20 dxe4 Nf3+ when White's own queen is lost. White looks an idiot here but Amin later recovered so well that he ended up tied first. At the end Qf1+ 34 Kg3 with Qe3+ forces mate.
